photo.description: Camera in 2000 had just 4 Mo memory stick so its why pictures have a 640x480 pixels definition - Montezuma Tuzigoot Arizona Directions from Phoenix to Montezuma Castle: take I-17 north to exit 289 Exit 289 and follow the signs 3 miles to the Visitor Center parking lot. From there, to get to Tuzigoot, go back to I-17 to the 260 cutoff toward Cottonwood. Take 279, the old road through Cottonwood, to Clarkdale and follow the signs to Tuzigoot. Montezuma Castle and Tuzigoot - 2000 - Patrick Nouhailler ©

photo.description: Mistletoe -- lots of it, &amp; easy to see here during the sycamores' brief leafless period -- the ranger said the sycamores shed their leaves and grow new ones almost immediately in this hot climate. Pretty sure this is Phoradendron macrophyllum. P. coryae is the only Arizona species that looked similar, but is found mainly on oaks, whereas macrophyllum is found on a variety of non-oak deciduous sp. P. tomentosum is the only species listed on the Montezuma's Castle checklist, but looks like the species has been split -- P. tomentosum sensu stricto is not found in AZ.
photo.tags: arizona flora az host sycamore mistletoe platanus nationalmonument parasite riparian parasitic verdevalley aztrip montezumascastlenationalmonument arizonasycamore viscaceae phoradendron hemiparasite hemiparasitic platanuswrightii coloradodesertmistletoe phoradendronmacrophyllum
photo.title: Any excuse for a kiss

photo.description: This is a large cenote (limestone sinkhole) with very interesting water chemistry. It's completely unlike anything else around in this area, and holds water year-round, making it an important site in this desert environment. Folks in the boat are biologists working on a project to trap and remove nonnative turtles (sliders -- a population introduced by people dumping unwanted pet turtles here) to protect the native Sonoran Mud Turtles. They're not endangered, but this is the northernmost extent of their range. And more importantly, the ecosystem of the Well is unique and fragile.
photo.tags: boat cenote limestone geology karst sinkhole nationalmonument montezumaswell montezumascastlenationalmonument
photo.title: Montezuma's Well

photo.description: Emesis zela. This species is found in the US only in a very restricted band along the Mogollon Rim in Arizona, although it is listed as common in appropriate habitat there -- namely, riparian sycamore woods, which is exactly where I found it. Got a good look thru binocs -- hindwing above bright orange with concentric dark banding, forewing above with dark shading along the central part of the median line. Unfortunately it didn't let me get a shot -- only one I got was a zoom macro with it perched far above our heads in a tree.
photo.tags: arizona orange butterfly lifelist small az lepidoptera nationalmonument riparian verdevalley aztrip metalmark emesis bmna ventral montezumascastlenationalmonument riodinidae emesiszela zelametalmark taxonomy:binomialemesiszela
photo.title: Zela Metalmark

photo.description: I learned this as Western Sycamore, but it looks like the Arizona has been split from the California -- or maybe it's only the Calif. that's called Western. At any rate, looks very similar to the ones I remember from Calif.; and distinctly different from the Eastern species (American Sycamore), which typically grows from a single, straight trunk &amp; has darker, peely bark all the way up, not just around the base.
photo.tags: arizona tree flora az sycamore trunk platanus nationalmonument riparian verdevalley aztrip platanaceae montezumascastlenationalmonument arizonasycamore platanuswrightii
photo.title: Arizona Sycamore

photo.description: Walnut Canyon National Monument is a United States National Monument located about 10 mi (16 km) southeast of downtown Flagstaff, Arizona, just off Interstate 40. The canyon rim lies at 6,690 ft (2,040 m); the canyon's floor is 350 ft lower. A 0.9 mi (1.4 km) long loop trail descends 185 ft (56 m) into the canyon passing 25 cliff dwelling rooms constructed by the Sinagua, a pre-Columbian cultural group that lived in Walnut Canyon from about 1100 to 1250 CE. Other contemporary habitations of the Sinagua people are preserved in the nearby Tuzigoot and Montezuma Castle national monuments. The Sinagua, who inhabitanted the dwellings in Walnut Canyon, left mysteriously around 1250 CE. It is thought that the Sinagua left because of fear of neighboring tribes or droughts, but it is not certain. The disappearance of the Sinagua left over 80 cliff dwellings behind. The dwellings themselves were small but large enough for the inhabitants to still be able to cook and sleep. Most of the cliff dwelling rooms are situated near the loop trail, typically slightly above the trail and immediately outside the loop itself. A typical room might have been the dwelling of a single family, and might measure approximately two meters high by six meters long by three meters deep. Because of the area's dry climate, the water present in the canyon was essential for its inhabitants over 700 years ago as it is for the animal and plant life that exists there today. There are many more dwellings to be seen up close in the canyon just east of the Monument, although it is illegal to actually enter the canyon because of the park's rules and regulations. Walnut Canyon was proclaimed a national monument on November 30, 1915 by President Woodrow Wilson in order to preserve the ancient cliff dwellings. It was transferred from the USDA Forest Service to the National Park Service on August 10, 1933. As with all historic areas administered by the National Park Service, the national monument was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on October 15, 1966. At Walnut Canyon, there are trails for tourists to get a close view of the dwellings. Walnut Canyon lies on the Colorado Plateau and cuts through the Permian Kaibab Limestone, which exposes the Toroweap Formation and Coconino Sandstone. The Kaibab formation also forms the rim of the Grand Canyon. Crossbedding is present in the Coconino Sandstone. Not all of Arizona is warm dry desert. At Walnut Canyon (6690'2039m above sea level), be prepared for snow in winter, hot sun in summer with afternoon thunderstorms, and, especially in spring, strong gusty winds on the rim andor in the canyon. Even though the climate was and still is somewhat harsh, the Sinagua Indians that lived there were able to harvest maize, beans and squash. Park entrance road, trails, and Visitor Center are open all year, except December 25. From May till October the monument is open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. MST and is open from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. MST the rest of the year. Entry to park trails closes 1 hour before the monument closes. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiWalnut_Canyon_National_Monument" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiWalnut_Canyon_National_Monument<a>

A 0.9 mi (1.4 km) long loop trail descends 185 ft (56 m) into the canyon passing 25 cliff dwelling rooms constructed by the Sinagua, a pre-Columbian cultural group that lived in Walnut Canyon from about 1100 to 1250 CE. Other contemporary habitations of the Sinagua people are preserved in the nearby Tuzigoot and Montezuma Castle national monuments. The Sinagua, who inhabitanted the dwellings in Walnut Canyon, left mysteriously around 1250 CE. It is thought that the Sinagua left because of fear of neighboring tribes or droughts, but it is not certain. The disappearance of the Sinagua left over 80 cliff dwellings behind. The dwellings themselves were small but large enough for the inhabitants to still be able to cook and sleep. Most of the cliff dwelling rooms are situated near the loop trail, typically slightly above the trail and immediately outside the loop itself. A typical room might have been the dwelling of a single family, and might measure approximately two meters high by six meters long by three meters deep. Because of the area's dry climate, the water present in the canyon was essential for its inhabitants over 700 years ago as it is for the animal and plant life that exists there today. There are many more dwellings to be seen up close in the canyon just east of the Monument, although it is illegal to actually enter the canyon because of the park's rules and regulations. Walnut Canyon was proclaimed a national monument on November 30, 1915 by President Woodrow Wilson in order to preserve the ancient cliff dwellings. It was transferred from the USDA Forest Service to the National Park Service on August 10, 1933. As with all historic areas administered by the National Park Service, the national monument was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on October 15, 1966. At Walnut Canyon, there are trails for tourists to get a close view of the dwellings. Walnut Canyon lies on the Colorado Plateau and cuts through the Permian Kaibab Limestone, which exposes the Toroweap Formation and Coconino Sandstone. The Kaibab formation also forms the rim of the Grand Canyon. Crossbedding is present in the Coconino Sandstone. Not all of Arizona is warm dry desert. At Walnut Canyon (6690'2039m above sea level), be prepared for snow in winter, hot sun in summer with afternoon thunderstorms, and, especially in spring, strong gusty winds on the rim andor in the canyon. Even though the climate was and still is somewhat harsh, the Sinagua Indians that lived there were able to harvest maize, beans and squash. Park entrance road, trails, and Visitor Center are open all year, except December 25. From May till October the monument is open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. MST and is open from 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. MST the rest of the year. Entry to park trails closes 1 hour before the monument closes. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiWalnut_Canyon_National_Monument" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiWalnut_Canyon_National_Monument<a>

photo.description: George Rothrock was the first photographer to set up shop in Phoenix (which is about a 100-mile drive south of here) and one of the pioneering photographers of the West. <a href"http:vintagephoto.comreferenceRothrockArticle.pdf">vintagephoto.comreferenceRothrockArticle.pdf<a> is an extensive article on him and has one of his photos of Montezuma's Well. (It's a stereo pair, too, although it's intended for a mechanical viewer so it's backwards when viewed cross-eyed).
